author: Pete Dougherty
title: Albany Devils lose season opener 4-1 in Binghamton
text:
Binghamton
Not all ends well that starts well, but the Albany Devils won't have to worry about that.
For the fifth time in their six seasons in Albany, the Devils got their American Hockey League campaign started with a loss.
Eric O'Dell scored twice, including the tie-breaking goal with 1:23 remaining in the second period, as the Binghamton Senators delivered a filibuster against the Devils 4-1 at the Veterans Memorial Arena.
"It's good that we have only one game this week," said rookie Joseph Blandisi , who scored the lone Albany goal. "We can go back to the drawing board and figure out what happened."
The Devils, who broke a four-year season-opening losing streak last year by winning at Adirondack, won't play again until a two-game series next Saturday and Sunday in Toronto.
"We still have things to work on," Devils coach Rick Kowalsky said. "It gives us some time, but the big thing is we've got the next three on the road.
"It's good to get the first game out of the way. We've got some good content for video."
Although Blandisi's goal came with Albany a man up, the Devils' power play was one of the main culprits.
Former Devils defenseman Mark Fraser took a double minor for Binghamton early in the second period — two minutes for roughing ex-teammate Mike Sislo , and two more for quibbling with referee David Banfield — but Albany didn't capitalize.
The Devils had another opportunity less than a minute after Fraser left the penalty box, but they failed to cash in.
"When you get six minutes of power play and don't get a goal, that was a huge confidence builder for them," said goaltender Yann Danis , who made 28 saves in his Albany debut. "For them to get that late goal in the second changed the momentum."
The goal was the result of a 2-on-1 break, finished when O'Dell took a pass from Tobias Lindberg to break a 1-1 tie.
David Dziurzynski was left alone in the slot early in the third to make it 3-1, and, as Danis said, "We weren't the same after that."
The Devils did hold a 33-32 edge in shots on goal but were outshot 12-5 in the third, when they were trying to come from behind and forcing offense.
"All those goals were very preventable," Kowalsky said. "It was just guys out of position, guys playing together for the first time, a lot of these guys. But we have to be a lot tighter in our own end than that."
The Devils had five rookies in the lineup, including Blandisi, who led the Ontario Hockey League with 52 goals last season.
It was easy to see why after he fired a shot that hit Binghamton defenseman Fredrik Claesson and ricocheted into the net.
"It was a good feeling when it first happened," Blandisi said. "It tied the game up at 1 there, but it's not as good when you lose."
"He's got a knack for the net," Kowalsky said. "That's a goal scorer's goal. ... He has the ability to score. The big thing is him committing and playing a 200-foot game."
SENATORS 4, DEVILS 1
Albany 1 0 0 — 1
Binghamton 1 1 2 — 4
